content.title: Sorting your laundry
content.description: Sorting your laundry is a the secret to keeping your clothes fresh, clean, and drama-free. By sorting, you’ll save time, protect your favorite fits, and make everything last longer. It’s like giving your clothes VIP treatment—and your wallet (and wardrobe) will thank you.

content.title: Sorting by color
content.description: Sorting by color is the first step to keeping your clothes looking fresh and vibrant. By separating whites, darks, and colors, you’ll prevent dye transfer and keep your clothes looking their best.

content.title: Sorting whites
content.description: Sorting whites is all about keeping your light-colored clothes looking bright and fresh. By separating whites from colors, you’ll prevent dye transfer and keep your whites looking their best. Whites typically include white shirts, socks, undergarments, and white sheets. They can often be washed with pastels.

content.title: Sorting darks
content.description: Dark clothes include grays, blues, blacks, and other dark colors, as well as pants, jeans, and sweatshirts.

content.title: Sorting colors
content.description: Brightly colored clothes can be washed together. This often includes athletic wear, t-shirts, and similar.

content.title: Sorting by fabric type
content.description: Sorting clothes by fabric type helps protect your clothes and improves wash efficiency.

content.title: Delicates and Lightweight fabrics
content.description: Delicate fabrics include lace, silk, and other lightweight materials. These items should be washed on a gentle cycle to prevent damage.

content.title: Cotton and natural fabrics
content.description: Cotton and natural fabrics are durable and can be washed together. This includes items like t-shirts, jeans, and towels.

content.title: Synthetics and blends
content.description: Synthetic fabrics include polyester, nylon, and blends. These items can be washed together on a regular cycle.

content.title: Heavy and bulky items
content.description: Heavy items, like comforters, rugs, coats, pillows, etc. should be washed separately to prevent damage to other items. These items can be washed on a heavy-duty cycle.

content.title: Sorting by soil level
content.description: Sorting by soil level helps ensure that heavily soiled items are cleaned properly without damaging other clothes.

content.title: Wash settings
content.description: Choosing the right wash settings is crucial for keeping your clothes looking their best. By selecting the appropriate cycle, temperature, and spin speed, you’ll ensure that your clothes are cleaned effectively without causing damage.

content.title: Wash cycle
content.description: The wash cycle determines how your clothes are cleaned. Different cycles are designed for different types of fabrics and soil levels. For example, a gentle cycle is best for delicates, while a heavy-duty cycle is ideal for heavily soiled items. Perm press is a medium cycle that is good for most items, especially synthetics.

content.title: Water temperature
content.description: Water temperature affects how well your clothes are cleaned. Hot water is best for whites and heavily soiled items, while cold water is gentler on colors and delicate fabrics.

content.title: Spin speed
content.description: Some machines let you choose spin speed. This determines how much water is removed from your clothes after washing. A higher spin speed removes more water but can be rougher on fabrics. A lower spin speed is gentler but may leave clothes wetter.

content.title: Reading labels
content.description: When in doubt, you can always consult the labels on your clothes. Labels provide important information about fabric content, care instructions, and wash settings. The symbols on the labels can be confusing, but are very sysetematic.

content.title: Label symbols: Wash
content.description: The wash symbol resembles the drum of a washing machine. The number or dots inside the tub indicates the maximum water temperature. The hand symbol indicates that the item should be hand washed.

content.title: Label symbols: Bleach
content.description: The triangle symbol indicates whether bleach can be used. A triangle with a cross through it means no bleach. A triangle with a 'CL' inside means only non-chlorine bleach can be used. A triangle with no cross or letters means any bleach can be used.

content.title: Label symbols: Dry
content.description: The square with a circle inside indicates that the item can be tumble dried. The dots inside the circle indicate the maximum heat setting. A square with a circle and a cross through it means do not tumble dry.

content.title: Label symbols: Iron
content.description: The iron symbol indicates whether the item can be ironed. The dots inside the iron indicate the maximum heat setting. An iron with a cross through it means do not iron.

content.title: Label symbols: Dry clean
content.description: The circle symbol indicates whether the item can be dry cleaned. A circle with a cross through it means do not dry clean. A circle with a 'P' inside means any solvent can be used. A circle with a 'F' inside means only petroleum solvent can be used.
